faqs.question: Les étrangers peuvent-ils acheter un bien immobilier en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreigners can freely purchase property in Spain without restrictions or residence requirements. UK citizens, EU nationals, and international investors simply require a Spanish tax identification number (NIE). The process typically completes within 30-60 days through a Spanish notary, and foreign ownership represents standard practice throughout the Costa Blanca.

faqs.question: Quels sont les frais d'achat d'un bien immobilier en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: Total acquisition costs in Spain typically range 7-10% of purchase price, comprising 6-7% transfer tax, 1-2% notary/legal fees, and registration costs. For this €179,900 property, total closing costs approximate €12,600-18,000. These represent standard and non-negotiable expenses throughout Spain, similar to transaction costs in comparable markets.

faqs.question: Combien coûtent les taxes foncières en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: Annual property tax (IBI) in Bigastro averages 0.4-0.5% of cadastral value annually, typically €400-600 for properties of this size. This remains significantly lower than UK council tax or Northern European property taxes, directly enhancing investment returns. Rental income tax at 19-37% (depending on individual circumstances) applies to holiday rental profits.

faqs.question: Puis-je obtenir un prêt hypothécaire en Espagne en tant qu'étranger ?
faqs.answer: Yes, Spanish banks provide mortgages to foreign buyers, typically offering 70-80% LTV at rates comparable to UK products (currently 3-4%). EU citizens access mortgages most easily, while non-EU nationals require additional documentation but regularly secure financing. Many investors prefer cash purchases eliminating currency risk and simplifying management.
